<title type="main">The Appearance on the way to Emmaus</title>
<description type="note">Preliminaries and introductory material omitted<lb/>The following plays have been taken from this source:</description>

<description type="note">Title: The appearance on the way to Emmaus.
Genre: English mystery and miracle plays.
<description type="note">Square brackets indicate sections of text unclear in the original and supplied by the current editor.</description>
[The Appearence on the way to Emmaus]

hic incipit aparicio cleophe et luce. Cleophas My brothir lucas I ?ow pray plesynge to ?ow if þat it be To þe castel of Emawus A lytyl way Þat ?e vowche-saf to go with me. lucas All redy brother I walke with the to ?one castell with ryght good chere Euyn to-gedyr Anon go we brother cleophas we to infere. Cleophas A brother lucas I am sore mevyd Whan cryst oure mayster comyth in my mynde whan that I thynke how he was grevyd Joye in myn herte kan I non fynde he was so lowlye so good so kynde holy of lyf and meke of mood Alas þe jewys þei were to blynde hym for to kylle þat was so good. lucas Brothyr cleophas ?e sey ful soth they were to cursyd and to cruell And judas þat traytour he was to loth Ffor gold and sylvyr his Mayster to selle the jewys were redy hym for to qwelle With skorgys bete out all his blood Alas þei were to fers and ffelle Shamfully þei henge hym on a rood. Cleophas ?a be-twen to Thevys Alas for shame they henge hym up with body rent Alas alas they were to blame to cursyd and cruel was þer intent Whan for thurste he was nere shent Ey?il and galle þei ?ovyn hym to drynke Alas for ruthe his deth thei bent in a ffowle place of horryble stynke. lucas ?a And cawse in hym cowde they non fynde Alas for sorwe what was here thought And he dede helpe bothe lame and blynde And all seke men þat were hym browght A-?ens vice Alwey he wrought synfull dede wold he nevyr do ?it hym to kylle þei sparyd nought Alas Alas why dede they so. Jhesus Well ovyr-take ?e serys in same to walke in felachep with ?ow I pray. lucas welcom serys in goddys name of good felachep we sey not nay. Jhesus Qwat is ?our langage to me ?e say that ?e haue to-gedyr ?e to sory and Evysum ?e ben Alway ?our myrthe is gon why is it so. Cleophas Sere me thynkyth þou art a pore pylgrym here walkynge be þi selfe A-lone and in þe cete of jerusalem þou knowyst ryght lytyl what þer is done Ffor pylgrymys comyn and gon ryth sone Ryght lytyl whyle pylgrymes do dwelle In all jerusalem as þou hast gone I trowe no tydyngys þat þou canst telle. Jhesus Why in Jerusalem what thynge is wrought What tydyngys fro thens brynge ?e. lucas A ther haue they slayn a man for nought gyltles he was as we telle the An holy prophete with god was he myghtyly in wurde and eke in dede of god he had ryght grett pooste Amonge þe pepyl his name gan sprede. he hyght jhesu of nazareth A man he was of ryght grett fame the jewys hym kylde with cruel deth. with-out trespas or Any blame hym to scorne they had grett game And naylid hym streyte on tyll a tre Alas Alas me thynkyth grett shame With-out cawse þat this xulde be. Cleophas ?a sere and ryght grett trost in hym we had All Israel countre þat he xulde saue the thrydde day is this þat he was clad in coold cley and leyd in grave ?itt woundyrful tydyngys of hym we haue Of women þat sought hym be-forn day lyth wethyr they sey truthe or ellys do raue We can not telle þe trew verdyth. Whan cryst in grave þei cowde not se they comyn to us And Evyn thus tolde How þat An Aungell seyd to them thre that he xuld leve with brest fful bolde ?itt petyr and johan preve this wolde to Crystys graue they ran thei tweyne and whan they come to þe graue so coolde They fownde þe women fful trewe sertayne. Jhesus A ?e Ffonnys And Slought of herte Ffor to be-leve in holy scrypture haue not prophetys with wurdys smerte Spoke be tokenys in signifure That Cryste xuld deye ffor ?our valure And syth entre his joye and blys why be ?e of herte so dure And trust not in god þat myghtful is. Bothe Moyses and Aaron and othyr mo in holy scrypture ?e may rede it of Crystis deth thei spak Also And how he xuld ryse out of his pitt Owt of ffeyth than why do ?e fflitte Whan holy prophetys ?ow teche so pleyne turne ?oure thought and chaunge ?our witte And truste wele þat cryst doth leve a-geyne. lucas Leve Ageyn man be in pes how xulde A ded man evyr A-ryse I cowncell þe such wurdys to ses Ffor dowte of pylat þat hy? justyce he was slayn At þe gre A-syse be cowncell of lordys many on Of suche langage take bettyr A-vise In every company þer þou dost gon. Christus Trewth dyd nevyr his maystyr shame Why xulde I ses than trewth to say Be Jonas þe prophete I preve þe same Þat was in a Whallys body iij nyghtis and iij day So longe Cryst in his grave lay As Jonas was with-inne þe se his grave is brokyn þat was of clay to lyff Resyn A?en now is he. Cleophas Sey nott so man it may not be thow thyn exaunple be sumdele good Ffor jonas on lyve evyr more was he And Cryst was slayn vpon A rood The Jewys on hym they were so wood Þat to his herte A spere they pyght he bled owt All his herte blood how xulde he thanne ryse with myght. Christus Take hede at Aaron and his dede styk Which was ded of his nature And ?it he floryschyd with flowrys ful thyk and bare Almaundys of grett valure The dede styk was signifure how cryst þat shamfully was deed and slayn As þat dede styk bare frute ful pure So cryst xuld ryse to lyve a-geyn. lucas That A deed styk ffrute xulde bere I merveyle sore þer of i-wys but ?itt hym sylf ffro deth to rere And leve A-geyn more woundyr it is That he doth leve I trost not this Ffor he hath bled his blood so red but ?itt of myrthe evyr moor I mys Whan I haue mende þat he is ded. Christus Why be ?e so hard of truste dede not Cryst reyse thorwe his owyn myght lazare þat deed lay vndyr þe duste And stynkyd ryght foule as I ?ow plyght To lyff Cryst reysid hym a-?en ful ryght out of his graue þis is serteyn why may nat Cryste hym self þus qwyght and ryse from deth to lyve Ageyn. Cleophas Now trewly sere ?our wurdys ben good I haue in ?ow ryght grett delyght I pray ?ow sere with mylde mood to dwelle with vs all þis nyght. Christus I must gon hens a-non ful ryght Ffor grett massagys I haue to do I wolde abyde yf þat I myght but at þis tyme I must hens go. lucas ?e xal not gon fro us þis nyght It waxit all derke gon is þe day þe sonne is downe lorn is þe lyght ?e xal not gon from vs A-way. Christus I may not dwelle As I ?ow say I must þis nyght go to my ffrende þerfore good bretheryn I ?ow pray lett me not my wey to wende. Cleophas Trewly from vs ?e xal not go ?e xal abyde with us here stylle ?our goodly dalyaunce plesyth us so We may nevyr haue of ?ow oure fylle We pray ?ow sere with herty wylle All nyght with us abyde And dwelle more goodly langage to talkyn vs tylle and of ?our good dalyaunce more ffor to telle. lucas ?a brothyr cleophas be myn Assent lete us hym kepe with strenth and myght Sett on ?oure hand with good entent And pulle hym with us þe wey well ryght The day is done sere and now it is nyght Why wole ?e hens now from us go ?e xal abyde as I ?ow plyght ?e xal not walke þis nyght vs ffro. Cleophas This nyght fro us ?e go not Away we xal ?ow kepe be-twen us tweyne to vs þerfore ?e sey not nay but walke with us þe wey is pleyne. Christus Sythyn ?e kepe me with myght and mayn With herty wyll I xal abyde. lucas of ?our abydyng we be fulfayn no man more wel-kom in þis werd wyde. Cleophas Off oure maystyr Cryst Jhesu Ffor ?e do speke so mech good I loue ?ow hertyly trust me trew he was bothe meke and mylde of mood Of hym to speke is to me food If ?e had knowe hym I dare wel say And in what plyght with hym it stood ?e wold haue thought on hym many A day. lucas Many A day ?a ?a i-wys he was a man of holy levynge Thow he had be þe childe of god in blys bothe wyse and woundyrfull was his werkynge But Aftere ?our labour and ferre walkynge takyth þis loff and etyth sum bred And than wyl we haue more talkynge Of Cryst oure maystyr þat is now ded. Christus Beth mery and glad with hert fful fre ffor of cryst jhesu þat was ?our ffrende ?e xal haue tydyngys of game and gle with-inne A whyle or ?e hens wende with myn hand þis bred I blys And breke it here as ?e do se I ?eve ?ow parte Also of þis this bred to ete and blythe to be. hic subito discedat christus ab oculis eorum. [Cleophas] A mercy god what was oure happe was not oure hert with loue brennynge Whan cryst oure mayster so nere oure lappe Dede sitte and speke such suete talkynge He is now quyk and man lyvenge þat fyrst was slayn and put in grave now may we chaunge all oure mornynge Ffor oure lord is resyn his seruauntys to saue. Lucas Alas for sorwe what hap was this Whan he dyd walke with vs in way he prevyd by scripture ryght wel i-wys þat he was resyn from vndyr clay We trustyd hym not but evyr seyd nay Alas for shame why seyd we so he is Resyn to lyve þis day out of his grave oure lord is go. Cleophas latt us here no lengere dwelle but to oure bretheryn þe wey we wende With talys trewe to them we telle that cryst doth leve oure mayster and frende. lucas I graunt þer-to with hert ful hende lete us go walke forthe in oure way I am ful joyfull in hert and mende þat oure lord levyth þat fyrst ded lay. Cleophas Now was it not goodly don of cryst jhesu oure mayster dere he hath with us a large wey gon And of his vprysyng he dede us lere Whan he walkyd with us in fere And we supposyd hym both dede and colde þat he was A-resyn ffrom vndyr bere be holy scripture þe trewth he tolde. lucas Ryght lovyngely don for-sothe this was What myght oure mayster tyl us do more Than us to chere þat fforth dede pas and ffor his deth we murnyd ful sore Ffor loue of hym oure myrthe was lore We were ffor hym ryght hevy in herte but now oure myrth he doth restore Ffor he is resyn bothe heyl and qwert. Cleophas That he is þus resyn I haue grett woundyr An hevy ston ovyr hym þer lay how shulde he breke þe ston A-soundyr þat was deed and colde in clay Euery man þis mervayle may And drede þat lord of mekyl myght but ?it of þis no man sey nay Ffor we haue seyn hym with opyn syght. lucas That he doth leve I woot wel this he is A-resyn with flesch and blood A levynge man for-sothe he is þat rewly was rent upon a rood All heyl dere brothyr and chaunge ?our mood Ffor cryst doth levyn and hath his hele We walkyd in wey with cryst so good and spak with hym wurdys fele. Cleophas Evyn tyll Emawus þe grett castell ffrom jerusalem with hym we went Syxti ffurlonge as we ?ow telle we went with hym evyn passent he spak with us with good entent þat Cryst xuld leve he tolde tyll us And previd it be scripture verament vade worlych nota worlych trust me trewe it is ryght thus. lucas ?a and whan he had longe spokyn vs tylle he wold ffrom vs agon his way with strenght and myght we keptyn hym stylle And bred we tokyn hym to etyn in fay he brak þe loff As Evyn on tway As ony sharpe knyff xuld kytt breed þer-by we knew þe trewth þat day þat cryst dede leve and was not deed. Petrus Now trewly serys I haue grett woundyr of these grete merveylis þat ?e vs telle In brekynge of bred fful evyn A-soundyr oure mayster ?e knew and lord ryght well ?e sey Cryst levith þat jewys dyd qwelle tyll us glad tydyngys þis is serteyn and þat oure mayster with ?ow so longe dede dwelle it doth well preve þat he levith a-geyn.
